------=_NextPart_000_0168_01C42BA3.29E566A0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Ken,

I have been thinking about this particular area.  It is possible that=
 you *do* want those larger values.  They may indicate that a particular fe=
ature (or set of features) are specifically higher in priority.  And the el=
evated weight values are a way for that node (or set of nodes) to drown out=
 noise to refine the "abstraction".

Now what this *might* mean is that the=
 other weights would be useful to "remove" so there is less need for the we=
ight (or subset of weights) to have their particular values advance so high=
 to compensate for the noise.

If the value range of the weights is clamped=
, it could produce a less efficient search.  When the weight that would jus=
t keep "elevating" hits the cap, to keep it's relative value to the other w=
eights feeding the node, all the other weights would need to go down propor=
tionally at the same time.  However, the odds of that happening are just ab=
out nil.  As such, I sense that that node will start to lose efficacy and t=
he search will wander away from what might have been a "key abstraction" or=
 "feature discovery".

I cannot prove any of this.  I am just using my intu=
ition here.


Jim O'Flaherty, Jr.


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From:=
 Kenneth Stanley 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, April 26, 200=
4 2:58 PM
  Subject: [neat] Re: Warning: Capping the maximum and minimum li=
nk weight may be important!


  Yuri, I think the problem with large connec=
tion weights is not so much
  "instability" as saturation.  That is, a netw=
ork with extremely large
  weights is likely to produce only 0's or 1's, be=
cause its sigmoid
  function is saturated.  Thus, the network wont be sensi=
tive to fine
  gradations in input.

  ken

  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"yurifromtomsk" <neuroevolution@m...> wrote:
  > Probably it's not good to =
have large weights of connections for the
  following reason. Consider one =
is solving a neural control task and
  his network has some "significant" (=
by their weights) connections.
  Then even slight change of input parameter=
 can lead to significant
  change of network outputs. I.e. network seems to=
 be easy to disbalance.
  > 
  > An interesting question appears. Described=
 above problem is
  concerning correlation level amidst i/o signals. Is the=
re any way to
  evaluate this parameter and whether its possible to use it =
in networks
  evolution? And more is there any way to check network stabili=
ty and
  quality? It can be useful because it will be possible to search fo=
r
  solution with some apriory defined charactersitics which seem to be
  m=
ore significant then total network complexity or something of this kind.
